document_data.name: Wanderings with Quill and Sword
document_data.author: [[Mirt]]
document_data.mainbody:
'''''Wanderings with Quill and Sword''''' was a [[book]] penned by [[Mirt the Moneylender]] in the mid–14{{th}} century [[DR]].
{{quote|''Finding one's true way in life can sometimes take an entire lifetime, for it is often the hardest task one faces–after finding out where the next meal is coming from, how to keep from freezing every winter night, where there's a sleeping-place safe from enemies, and just who one can trust to share it with, that is. Oh, aye and finding the time to do all of these things...''|Excerpt from ''Wanderings with Quill and Sword''}}
document_data.History:
{{quote|''Some kings sit upon more bloody thrones than this one, mind. When they talk business, 'tis all blood, blades, and bitter words.''|Excerpt from ''Wanderings with Quill and Sword''}}
The autobiographical collection of musings was published in the {{YearlinkName|1349}} and a copy of the book was kept in the great fortress-library of [[Candlekeep]] as of the {{YearlinkName|1372}}.{{Cite web/The Candlekeep Collection}}
